elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
SCENE 1: INT. THE BIRTHDAY ROOM
FX: A WOMAN BREATHING, LONG DEEP INTAKES. LOW HUM OF ELECTRONIC
- INCLUDING REGULAR ‘BLIP’ OF A HEART MONITOR:

(SOFT-SPOKEN, TEARY AT TIMES) I’m not sure if you remember this - you were only small - but I used to have you up on my shoulders sometimes, and we’d go along the side of the canal. You’d be too big for it now, little pickle, but back then you’d point at everything and want to know what it was - and I could tell you what almost everything was. But sometimes you’d point at a bird or a tree, and you’d want to know what type of a bird or a tree it was - and I wouldn’t know the answer. So I’d make it up! My love, I’m afraid there’s no such thing as a Saw-End Duck or a Great Marmaduke Tree. I hope you’re not too disappointed, but I rather enjoyed inventing them. And you did smile.
— FILLED BY FX: HEART MONITOR.

I don’t want any of you to worry. I know you will, but you shouldn’t. I’m going to be alright - I’1l be with your father soon. I’ve missed him a lot, you know. Maybe I’m looking forward to this, in a funny sort of way. But I’m going to miss you all dearly.
FX: SOMETHING ELECTRONIC POWERING UP...
I can feel it coming now. Chloe, tell Sophie I love her - I know she’1l be too young to understand, but do tell her.
Ten, nine, eight, seven -
(PANICKED) Oh no, please, can I have a little more time?
Six, five, four -
(HURRIED) I love you, my darlings, I love you so much.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 4
Three, two, one.
(DEEP BREATH) Goodbye.
Zero. Happy birthday, and welcome to the End.
FX: HUGE ZAAAAP! HEART MONITOR FLATLINES.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 2: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: LANDING CHIME. DOCTOR CHECKS VARIOUS CONTROLS AS INTERIOR
OPENS AND FLIP FOLLOWS CONSTANCE IN.
Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you, happy birthday dear Connie, happy -
Yes, that’s quite enough of that, thank you.
I can’t believe you weren’t going to tell me. That’s well sneaky, that is.
I prefer not to make a fuss about it, and I don’t expect today to be any different.
So come on, Con — how old are you, exactly?
(AT CONTROLS) Mrs Ramon! A lady should not be required to disclose her age.
I see we’ve landed. I think some fresh air may be in order?

I don’t think it’ll be quite fresh, Mrs Clarke. I’m detecting a heavily recycled atmosphere. But it apppears they’ve added a little bit of flavouring — rather like lemon sherbert — so it should be quite tolerable.
Let’s head out, then. Please.
FX: TARDIS DOORS OPEN. AS THEY EXIT:
For she’s a jolly good fellow, for she’s a jolly good fellow, for she’s a jolly good fe-e-llow -
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 6
SCENE 3: EXT. ROOFTOP [CONTINUOUS]
FX: THEY WALK OUT. A WIND BLOWS; SENSE OF BEING UP A HEIGHT.
Now that is quite a view. “Jocund day stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops” — as a predecessor of mine once said.
Your predecessor was Shakespeare?
Well, no, but he did think rather highly of himself.
FX: DOCTOR CLOSES TARDIS DOOR. TECHNOLOGY — TRANSPORTS DRIVING
BY, DRONES FLYING BY.
Oooo — flying stuff!
What do you think? Busy city, technologically quite advanced... I’d say an Earth colony, judging by the architecture.
Doctor. You can’t possibly know that at a glance.
I dunno - he is a bit of an Earth Spotter, isn’t he, our Doctor? With his pocket guide to human stuff and his little pencil to circle what he sees.
Yes, thank you, Flip. I like to call it using my eyes. And I also spy what looks like the limestone roof of a cavern up through the clouds.
Roof?!
Somewhere subterranean, with its own eco-system. Impressive.
Like the inside of a stone snowglobe. I’m suddenly feeling slightly claustrophobic.
Why, does it come on with old age?
(NOT TOO ANNOYED) Oh, for goodness’ sake...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 7
Come on, no secrets, not between us. I’m nineteen, he’s nine- hundred-and-whatever-he-says-today, and you are...?
(SIGH) Thirty-five. I am thirty-five.
Aha!
Now, can we leave it at that?
Doctor, this had better be Planet Ibiza, or something - cus I’ve got a Wren Party to organise!
FX: FAR BELOW - CARNIVAL PROCESSION PASSING. SPACE-Y
INSTRUMENTS.
I do hope we can find something better to do. Even a spot of deadly peril would be fine.
Well, I’m sure some deadly peril will be along in due course, Mrs Clarke. But you may be in luck, Flip — it looks like they’re having some kind of carnival down below...
(PEERS) That should do the trick.
I must say, I’m far more curious about that glass structure beyond the square...
Quite magnificent, isn’t it?
(WORLD OF HER OWN) I could get masks made. — Cardboard masks with your face on, Connie.
Why on Earth would you want to do that?
If my calculations are correct, that glass spire stands at the dead centre of the city — a column protruding from street level right the way to the roof of the cavern.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 8
The whole thing’s revolving — it’s beautiful, the way it catches the light. Speaking of which — if we’re underground, why is it daylight?
Heavy duty floodlights, I’d say. We’re in the middle of a technological marvel.
In that case, there’s got to be somewhere round here I can get some T-shirts made. Who fancies a trot down a fire escape? (AS
DISAPPEARS OFF) WREN PARTY!
I really don’t want all this fuss.
I’m not sure you’ve much choice in the matter. Come along, Mrs Clarke.
FX: THEY FOLLOW FLIP.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 4: INT. MIDDLE OFFICE
FX: YORK APPROACHES HIS DESK.
Happy birthday!
FX: SMALL ELECTRONIC BIRTHDAY JINGLE — CONTINUING. [NB: DO NOT
‘HAPPY BIRTHDAY TO YOU’ — IN COPYRIGHT. ]
Oh good grief...
Welcome to your desktop. Congratulations on reaching your sixty-first year, Mr York.
(HUSHED) Look, I’d rather not make a fuss. I don’t want the rest of the office finding out if I can help it.
I understand, sir. My sincere apologies on this happy day.
FX: BIRTHDAY JINGLE STOPS ABRUPTLY.
(SITTING DOWN) Computer, what... is... this?
It is a cake. Your colleagues Gresh, Kayden and Wayne left it here for you.
Who told them? Is this some kind of joke?
FX: MIDDLEMAN WALKS UP THROUGH —
No, it is a cake. Ingredients: eggs, flour, sugar, butter, baking powder, cocoa powder. Calorie breakdown: thirty-nine per cent fats, fifty-seven per cent carbohydrates, four per cent [protein. ]
Well, it’s going in the bin.
FX: HE PICKS UP THE CAKE, BUT IS INTERRUPTED.
Many happy returns, Callum. One step closer to the End, eh?
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 10
Sorry, Middleman, I didn’t realise you were [there -]
And what a delightful cake.
A gift from my generous colleagues, sir.
How thoughtful. Your age today?
Sixty; Sirs
I see. Ten more years. How does that feel? I must say, I’m not looking forward to it myself — too much to do first.
I am excited at the prospect. The great unknown.
Your departure will benefit your world. You’ve done such good service already. How marvellous to know you still have the ultimate contribution ahead.
Do you mind me asking, Siv...
What?
Well, I don’t think you’ve ever said. What is your age, sir?
That’s classified, I’m afraid.
Oh, of course. I'm Sorry, Sir.
But do enjoy your cake.
Thank you, sir.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 11
SCENE 5: EXT. MARKETPLACE
FX: ALIEN-Y MUSIC AS BEFORE. LAUGHING, CHEERING CROWDS. A
ATMOSPHERE. CONTINUES THROUGH ENTIRE SCENE.
NB: ALL B/G VOICES AUDIBLY UNDER 35. VERY IMPORTANT.
(OFF; U-35) Fried tailgrot - who wants some tailgrot?!
[WILDTRACK] (CHEERING — AS IN CHILLI-EATING CONTEST) Five, four, three, two, one..! — Aaaaaah!!
Doctor! This is perfect.
That’s one way of putting it. I’ve never seen so much public debauchery.
Just you wait for V.E. Day.
I’m sorry?
SELLER Fried tailgrot, Miss?
It looks revolting.
SELLER Lovely with a bit of pink sauce, that!
I rather like it down here. Everything’s so vibrant.
You would think that.
(TO MARKET SELLER) Go on, I’1l try some — what was it? Tailgrot? Got no cash, mind.
SELLER You’re alright, I like your smile. (FX: SPLOP IN CARDBOARD BOX) Here you go.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 12
Aw, thanks. (MOUTHFUL) Actually... that’s not bad! Tastes of grapefruit. Meaty grapefruit!
SELLER Best grub in Formicia.
Formicia? Is that where we are?
SELLER Eh?
Don’t mind her — she’s got birthday brain. Right, you two stay here — I’m gonna go find us a party.
Philippa!
(EXITING) You’1ll love it, Connie!
Oh my...
She means well.
I know. She’s got so much energy — she makes me feel...
Yes, quite.
Do you not ‘do’ birthdays, Doctor?
I lost track of all that a long time ago.
I’m sure the TARDIS could keep track for you. If you wanted. With some kind of alarm, perhaps?
As you know, Mrs Clarke — I am not a Time Lord to be scheduled.
Indeed. (BEAT) That billboard, Doctor — what do you make of it?
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 13
‘The End is the Beginning’? — Well, it’s an advertising slogan, I suppose. Advertising what, I couldn’t say.
It reminds me of the War Office posters — a call to arms.
FX: FLIP ARRIVES BACK — WITH A NEW FRIEND IN TOW...
Doctor, Constance, I want you to meet Chloe — it was Chloe, yeah?
Yeah! — Nice to meet you! Whose birthday is it, then?
That would be me.
Chloe’s got some spare tickets to an all-nighter in the West Square — come on, do we fancy it? Wren party! Wren party!
I’m not sure —
(EYEING UP THE DOCTOR) Hang about. You didn’t mention him.
What?
I’m sorry. She can come, but not him.
I beg your pardon?
You’ll have to leave him here.
I’m afraid we can’t —
Come on. They’1l catch up with him, you know. Sooner or later.
Eh? It’s just the Doctor!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 14
Look, he’s not my problem. I’1l be here at nine if you still want to come. And as for you...
Yes?
You should be ashamed of yourself.
FX: CHLOE LEAVES.
Was it something I said?
Well. Some new B.F.F. she turned out to be. Sorry about that.
What exactly were you supposed to be ashamed of?
The list is potentially endless. — She seemed very serious though, didn’t she?
Maybe curly hair is illegal here? Or Time Lords — maybe they hate Time Lords! Anyway, we’ve still got to find you a party, Connie.
Look, Flip, I really appreciate you wanting to do this for me — I do. But can’t we do something a little quieter? On a smaller scale?
Got it: spa!
Spa?
Do it for my Mum every year. She goes loopy for a spa day. How would you feel, Connie, about a proper birthday pamper?
I’m not sure. The last time we visited a spa...
That was back in seventeen hundred and something! On the other Side of the square, I saw this place that looked like a health spot — massages, facials, that kind of thing. Only with robots.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 15
(UNIMPRESSED) I suppose it had to be with robots.
Well, you ladies will just have to carry on in my absence.
Come on, Doctor. Do you the world of good. Take the weight of the universe off your shoulders.

Flip, I’ve lived for nearly a millennium, fought innumerable intergalactic tyrants, liberated countless worlds and civilisations — and I’ve never once felt the slightest inclination to receive a robot massage.
Well, maybe that’s why you’re so wound up all the time.
All that lying around — far too close to sleeping for my liking.
Then again, I suppose it sounds rather more civilised than a... Wren Party?
That’s right!
Is it?
Oh, do let’s go, Doctor. I have to confess, I’m coming round to the idea.
As it’s your birthday, Mrs Clarke.
Alright! But we’re still calling it a Wren Party.
FX: AS THEY SET OFF —
I’ve a feeling I’m going to regret this...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 6: INT. MIDDLE OFFICE
FX: YORK OPERATING ELECTRONICS AT HIS DESK.
Computer — camera three-four-two, please.
Three-four-two full screen.
Hold on. Please check colour balance.
Colour balance correct.
That coat actually looks like that?!
Registering seventy-six individual colour tones.
Staggering exhibitionism. I take it these are our unregistered civilians?
Correct. Ages not logged for all three individuals.
Alright, dispatch a scan drone.
Dispatching.
FX: REPEATING BEEP.
Mr York. We have a new arrival in the Birthday Room.
Thank you. Please patch it through to the Middleman’s office — he was keen to congratulate anyone reaching the End this afternoon.
Connecting now.
I think it’s perverse. A computer could do it. I think he enjoys it...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 7: INT. THE BIRTHDAY ROOM
FX: HEART MONITOR AGAIN. MIDDLEMAN’S VOICE OVER SPEAKERS.
Where am I?
(D) Happy birthday, Javonte.
It’s finally happening, then.
(D) You are close to the End. I’m so proud to be able to usher you through... personally.
Please, please, I’m not ready. You can’t make me go.
(D) It’s time to record your last message, Javonte. Choose your words with care — for the sake of your family. Ready?
FX: BEEP TONE.

I have no choice in this, so.. Gaynor, please don’t be too unhappy, we’ll be back together soon. I still remember the day we met. You were sat across from me on the transport — arms crossed, staring out of the window, and I leaned over and said hello... and you didn’t tell me to get lost. I.. Please, do we have to do this? I don’t want this. I don’t.
(D) Your departure will benefit your world.
You can’t just decide what’s best for me!
(D) Computer — time remaining?
Twelve seconds until the End.
Please take over. This creature isn’t worth my time. (TO JAVONTE) So many souls that pass this way do so with the courage you apparently lack.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 18
Eight, seven, six...
I’m sorry, I didn’t mean what I said...
. five, four, three...
I’m sorry!
. two, one, zero. Happy birthday, and welcome to the End.
FX: AS BEFORE — HUGE ZAAP. HEART MONITOR FLATLINES.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 19
SCENE 8: INT. SPA
FX: THUDDING OF ROBOT HANDS ON DOCTOR’S BACK — GENTLY MIRRORING
BEAT OF HEART MONITOR.
Proceeding from lower back to shoulders. Are you going anywhere nice on holiday this year, sir?
(VOICE WOBBLING AS MASSAGE CONTINUES) Flip?
Yes, Doctor?
This is doing very little for my tension!
Well, I’m beginning to feel... surprisingly relaxed. (REACTS IN A
WAY TO BEING MASSAGED THROUGHOUT THE REST OF THE SCENE)
The whole experience is giving me robophobia. (GETTING OFF
BENCH) I’m sorry, no!
Doctor, don’t you dare run off!
Is something the matter, sir?
I had a better time stretched out on the rack in the Tower of London. Mrs Clarke, Mrs Ramon, please excuse me. I shall see you later. (EXITS)
Stop massage. (GETS UP, CALLING AFTER) Doctor, come back! Doctor! — Doctor, you’re useless...
FX: A GIRL ON THE NEXT BED CHIMES IN.
What’s your mate’s problem? Apart from the obvious.
Proceeding to full pedicure.
Thank you, computer.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 20
Don’t mind him. — What are you having done?
Oh, everything — it’s not worth doing if you don’t have the whole lot. They’ve got a special on diamond-tipped eyelashes now — did you hear?
That sounds... nice?
Might try that today. Have you been before?
First time.
I pretty much live here. Spa all day, party all night — that’s the life.
That sounds amazing. I’m Flip by the way — nice to get a robo- massage beside you.
Olivia. Likewise.
So you just do this all day? You don’t have to work?
Why would I? I’m only twenty-six.
Well jel. Young people don’t have to work? I could get to like it here.
What do you mean ‘here’?
Nothing.
Working’s what parents are for. My Dad’s been head down in the Middle for years to let me do what I want out here, bless him.
The Middle?
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 21
Yeah, course. (CONFIDENTIALLY) Look, do you mind me asking...?
(CONFIDENTIALLY BACK) What?
Your two friends... how old are they?
Ha! You can’t ask that — Mrs Clarke here’s a lady! (WHISPERS) A lady who’s turning thirty-five...
Ah, so that’s why you’re here? A goodbye party?
Goodbye to what?
Well, her freedom.
What?
And your older gent — you know, he really shouldn’t be out in public. He’s so obvious.
I’ve been saying that for ages — but look, what do you mean by
They’1l arrest him, you know.
You know, you’re the second person to... why would they want arrest him?
Well. As a coward.
The Doctor’s lots of things, but he’s definitely not a coward.
He’s here, isn’t he? So he’s shirking his duties.
Yeah — he’s shirking with me. He’s my friend.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 22
I shouldn’t even be talking to you. — In fact, I really shouldn’t. Pedicure off, please.
Pedicure halted.
FX: AS OLIVIA GETS UP —
Hey, wait -
See you around, OK? Just not with your friends. (EXITS)
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 9: INT. MIDDLE OFFICE
Computer, I’d like to send my birthday message now.
Now recording sixtieth birthday message. You have ten remaining until the End.
Computer, deactivate yourself — I’d like to say this in private.
FX: POWERING DOWN SOUND.

Hey. It’s me. Hope I don’t look too different. A bit more grey, a few more lines, but still your old Dad. Sixty today — didn’t want to make a fuss, obviously. I saw you on the cameras yesterday — on West Square, I think. I always wonder if you’1ll somehow know I’m watching and give me a wave. It’s not happened yet. That’s the problem with these annual messages — so hard to have an actual chat. Anyway, I’m still looking forward to your next one. Ten more to go for me. I used to think I'd be excited about it — happy to make the ultimate sacrifice. But the closer I get, the more it scares me. And I think the outlook is worse these days. There’s a lot of chatter here.. that something big is coming. All to do with the End. So just... be careful, OK? Be really careful. And... I love you.
FX: PRESSES ‘SEND’ BUTTON.
Computer - reactivate.
Good evening, Mr York.
Look... can I record that again? I wasn’t happy with that.
Your birthday message has now been sent. Next communication available in one year.
Many happy returns...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 10: EXT. SPA
FX: OUR TRIO ARE WALKING AWAY.
Doctor, I really don’t know why you had to kick up such a fuss.
My dear Constance, when one has been strangled by as many androids as I have, you’d rather not pay for the privilege.
Doctor, that girl I was next to — she was saying you were illegal too.
Well, you can tell her that I have been tried for my crimes on more than one occasion — and I’ve always been acquitted.
(SENSING SOMETHING WASN’T RIGHT) ‘Older gent’. That’s what she called you. An ‘older gent’
(REALISATION) Goodness gracious.
Yeah — that’s it, isn’t it?!
(BAFFLED) What’s what?
We’ve met, like, I don’t know how many people now? And they’ve all been young.
Everyone in the square. Everyone in the spa.
Ever since we landed, we’ve seen no-one old. No-one middle- aged, even!
(LOOKING AROUND) Really? Well... (BIT DESPERATE) Maybe all this is part of a university campus, perhaps??
You don’t think that. Doctor, I think there’s something weird
going on round here.
FX: BUZZING OVERHEAD.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 25
What’s that?
FX: BUZZING FLIES DOWN CLOSER.
Some kind of drone...
Jared's mate got one of those — flew it near Heathrow and they shot it down. Hello, little cutie!
Unregistered citizens... scanning, scanning.
FX: THE DRONE IS NOW BUZZING AROUND THEM, CLOSE.
Oi, watch it!
I daresay this is rather more sophisticated than anything one of Jared’s mates might be able to acquire. It reminds me of an oculoid tracker...
Age scan activate.
Doctor, what’s it doing? What’s that red light?
FX: ELECTRONIC SCAN.
Just let it scan you, Flip. Maybe it’1l help give us some answers about this odd place.
Is it safe?
Scans tend to be — even red ones - how do you feel?
Fine, I think — just a bit blinded.
Subject age.. nineteen. Registered Beginning.
Cheeky, ain’t he?
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 26
FX: DRONE BUZZES OVER TO CONSTANCE.
I think it’s my turn.
FX: SCAN SOUND AGAIN.
Subject age... thirty-four. Sixteen minutes remaining till Middle.
Oh, right — so technically it’s not your birthday yet?
Evidently not. Although quite how it knows that is beyond me.
FX: DRONE BUZZES TO DOCTOR.
Ah, now I may be something of a surprise to you...
Scanning, scanning...
FX: ELECTRONIC SOUND SEEMS TO GO WRONG (SYSTEM CAN’T CALCULATE
THE DOCTOR’S AGE).

Subject age... subject age... ninety-eight, ninety-eight, one hundred and seventy-six, three hundred and twenty-one, four hundred and fifty-seven, six hundred and forty-six — six — six — Z2zzix, zZZZixxx.. systems overloading. Systems overloading.
Serves you right for being such a nosey parker!
Subject too old for system calibrations.
Well, of all the cheek!
Z2Z2Z.. 2zz.. Correction. Subject designated over seventy. Proceed to the End.
Now, what do you mean by —
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 27
End.
FX: DIFFERENT TYPE OF SOUND — A TRANSMAT POWERING UP.
Doctor, what’s it doing? It’s shaking!
Oh dear. Flip, Constance, whatever you do —
FX: RISING SOUND BECOMES A ZASH! ... AND THE DOCTOR IS GONE.
He’s gone!
(TO DRONE) OI! What did you just do to our friend?
Subject has been transported to the End.
You bring him back right now!
Registration complete.
FX: FLIES OFF.
Come back! Where’s Heathrow security when you need them?
Sixteen minutes.
What?
It said ‘sixteen minutes’ when it scanned me. until Middle’.
A countdown?
A countdown to what?
Whatever it is, it’s sixteen minutes from now. Probably fifteen minutes now.
‘Sixteen minutes
Or from then.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 28
Until what? Oh, Flip, this is just typical — I didn’t even want a birthday fuss!
Well, it wasn’t me who brought us to the planet of the Age Police!
The Middle. What’s the Middle?
Olivia...
What?
That girl in the spa — Olivia — she said her Dad works at the Middle.
Well... we need to go and find her then — quickly!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 11: INT. THE BIRTHDAY ROOM
FX: TRANSMAT MATERIALISATION — REVERSE FX IN PREVIOUS SCENE?
Gngh... transmats always make my spine rattle. And — (FINDS
RESTRAINED) — you know, it’s not nice to be teleported into restraints! Not nice at all. Hello! — Is anyone listening?
FX: LIFE SUPPORT MONITOR — TWO HEARTBEATS, OF COURSE.
Query: double heartbeat detected. Recalibrating.
FX: QUIET HUMS, BRRS, BEEPS AND COMPUTER RESETS ITSELF.
Computer? Computer, this is not on! I demand you return me to my friends at once!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 12: EXT. MARKETPLACE
FX: CONSTANCE AND FLIP RUNNING THROUGH MARKET. BUSY B/G FX AS
BEFORE.
How long do we have — I mean, how long do I have?
Six minutes or so, I think. That’s a guess!
I’m close to the Middle. But the Doctor — that machine said he was at ‘the End’...
Doesn’t sound too rosy, does it?
It does not. Is that why there are no older people here? Is there some sort of cull? Goodness, it’s too horrible to think about.
Hey, I’m sure the Doctor will have a trick up his sleeve.
I certainly hope so.
Ah, I see her — Olivia — she’s over there, just leaving the spa! (CALLING) Olivia! Liv!
FX: THEY CATCH HER UP.
Oh, hello. What happened to your illegal friend?
Olivia, you have to help us. The Doctor was scanned by some kind of robot —
A drone!
A drone. It said I was sixteen minutes from the Middle — what does that mean?
Oh, come on — don’t ask silly questions. What is it with you lot?
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 31
Look, we’re really thick, ok? Unbelievably stupid. Please, just tell us!
Well — that’s the Middle, over there.
The glass tower?
That’s the centre of government. That’s where you’re going.
I am?
You’re turning thirty-five, so I’m afraid the fun times are over. They’1ll put you to work — doing all the jobs that keep Formicia going. Boring but... that’s life.
I’d hate to be considered a shirker, but I can’t say it appeals.
You’ve got no choice.
Look, our friend — it scanned him and it said he was very old. Then it said something about ‘the End’ and it, you know, vanished him.
The End? I didn’t think he looked that old. You must give me the number of his plastic surgeon.
But what does it mean — the End?
Well, it’s the End. You won’t see him again.
FX: BUZZING ABOVE.
Connie — that drone...
It’s come back for me.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 32
OK, we should run.
No, Flip. You heard what Olivia said. I’ve got no choice. Maybe I can get some answers in the Middle, find out what’s happened to the Doctor — before it’s too late.
Scanning... scanning...
Are you sure?
No.
Subject age... thirty-five. Process to the Middle.
FX: TRANSMAT BEAM, AS BEFORE.
(FADING AWAY) All this fuss over a silly little birthday...
FX: TRANSMAT FINISHES. DRONE BUZZES OFF.
She’s gone. What am I supposed to do now?
(HER VOICE SOUNDING MORE MATURE — LESS OF A POSE) You really don’t know any of this, do you?
Look, me and my friends — we’re not from around here. As if you hadn’t guessed.
But that’s not possible — this is all there is. There’s nothing beyond Formicia.

DOCTOR: Oh dear. Flip, Constance, whatever you do —
CONSTANCE: He’s gone!
FLIP: (TO DRONE) OI! What did you just do to our friend?
DRONE: Subject has been transported to the End.
FLIP: You bring him back right now!
DRONE: Registration complete.
FLIP: Come back! Where’s Heathrow security when you need them?
CONSTANCE: Sixteen minutes.
FLIP: What?
CONSTANCE: It said ‘sixteen minutes’ when it scanned me. until Middle’.
FLIP: A countdown?
CONSTANCE: A countdown to what?
FLIP: Whatever it is, it’s sixteen minutes from now. Probably fifteen minutes now.
FLIP: ‘Sixteen minutes
FLIP: Or from then.
FLIP: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 28
CONSTANCE: Until what? Oh, Flip, this is just typical — I didn’t even want a birthday fuss!
FLIP: Well, it wasn’t me who brought us to the planet of the Age Police!
CONSTANCE: The Middle. What’s the Middle?
FLIP: Olivia...
CONSTANCE: What?
FLIP: That girl in the spa — Olivia — she said her Dad works at the Middle.
CONSTANCE: Well... we need to go and find her then — quickly!
CONSTANCE: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 29
CONSTANCE: SCENE 11: INT. THE BIRTHDAY ROOM
DOCTOR: Gngh... transmats always make my spine rattle. And — (FINDS
HIMSELF: RESTRAINED) — you know, it’s not nice to be teleported into restraints! Not nice at all. Hello! — Is anyone listening?
COMPUTER: Query: double heartbeat detected. Recalibrating.
DOCTOR: Computer? Computer, this is not on! I demand you return me to my friends at once!
DOCTOR: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 30
DOCTOR: SCENE 12: EXT. MARKETPLACE
DOCTOR: BEFORE.
CONSTANCE: How long do we have — I mean, how long do I have?
FLIP: Six minutes or so, I think. That’s a guess!
CONSTANCE: I’m close to the Middle. But the Doctor — that machine said he was at ‘the End’...
FLIP: Doesn’t sound too rosy, does it?
CONSTANCE: It does not. Is that why there are no older people here? Is there some sort of cull? Goodness, it’s too horrible to think about.
FLIP: Hey, I’m sure the Doctor will have a trick up his sleeve.
CONSTANCE: I certainly hope so.
FLIP: Ah, I see her — Olivia — she’s over there, just leaving the spa! (CALLING) Olivia! Liv!
OLIVIA: Oh, hello. What happened to your illegal friend?
CONSTANCE: Olivia, you have to help us. The Doctor was scanned by some kind of robot —
FLIP: A drone!
CONSTANCE: A drone. It said I was sixteen minutes from the Middle — what does that mean?
OLIVIA: Oh, come on — don’t ask silly questions. What is it with you lot?
OLIVIA: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 31
FLIP: Look, we’re really thick, ok? Unbelievably stupid. Please, just tell us!
OLIVIA: Well — that’s the Middle, over there.
CONSTANCE: The glass tower?
OLIVIA: That’s the centre of government. That’s where you’re going.
CONSTANCE: I am?
OLIVIA: You’re turning thirty-five, so I’m afraid the fun times are over. They’1ll put you to work — doing all the jobs that keep Formicia going. Boring but... that’s life.
CONSTANCE: I’d hate to be considered a shirker, but I can’t say it appeals.
OLIVIA: You’ve got no choice.
FLIP: Look, our friend — it scanned him and it said he was very old. Then it said something about ‘the End’ and it, you know, vanished him.
OLIVIA: The End? I didn’t think he looked that old. You must give me the number of his plastic surgeon.
CONSTANCE: But what does it mean — the End?
OLIVIA: Well, it’s the End. You won’t see him again.
FLIP: Connie — that drone...
CONSTANCE: It’s come back for me.
CONSTANCE: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 32
FLIP: OK, we should run.
CONSTANCE: No, Flip. You heard what Olivia said. I’ve got no choice. Maybe I can get some answers in the Middle, find out what’s happened to the Doctor — before it’s too late.
DRONE: Scanning... scanning...
FLIP: Are you sure?
CONSTANCE: No.
DRONE: Subject age... thirty-five. Process to the Middle.
CONSTANCE: (FADING AWAY) All this fuss over a silly little birthday...
FLIP: She’s gone. What am I supposed to do now?
OLIVIA: (HER VOICE SOUNDING MORE MATURE — LESS OF A POSE) You really don’t know any of this, do you?
FLIP: Look, me and my friends — we’re not from around here. As if you hadn’t guessed.
OLIVIA: But that’s not possible — this is all there is. There’s nothing beyond Formicia.
FLIP: You sure about that, Olivia?
FLIP: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 33
FLIP: SCENE 13: INT. MIDDLEMAN’S SUITE
COMPUTER: Sir, pre-programmed target located.
MIDDLEMAN: You’ve found her? Show me.
OLIVIA: You really don’t know any of this, do you?
MIDDLEMAN: Yes, that’s her. She thought she could hide... but a little detective work was all it needed.
COMPUTER: Subject lock — procedure?
MIDDLEMAN: Cloaked — we need to keep this under wraps.
COMPUTER: Activating.
MIDDLEMAN: Goodbye, Miss Olivia.
MIDDLEMAN: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 34
MIDDLEMAN: SCENE 14: EXT. MARKETPLACE
OLIVIA: Look, if you’re telling the truth, there’s something I should —
SPILLING: APPLES ACROSS THE SQUARE. THERE ARE SCREAMS.
MARKET TRADERS: [WILDTRACK ]
FLIP: Erm. That stall just exploded. Was that supposed to happen?
OLIVIA: We're in danger.
FLIP: What is that? I don’t see anything, but —
MARKET: SELLER Hey, my shop! Who did that?
OLIVIA: (TO FLIP) I’m sorry — this is my fault. They want me dead.
FLIP: Who does?
OLIVIA: I thought I was hidden — like this assassin they’ve sent. Evidently his disguise is better than mine.
FLIP: There’s something there — like a huge animal. I can’t see it.
FLIP: But I can hear it.
OLIVIA: Run!!!
OLIVIA: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 35
OLIVIA: SCENE 15: INT. BIRTHDAY ROOM
COMPUTER: Recalibration complete. Echo in monitoring system confirmed.
DOCTOR: Well, hadn’t you better get me out of here, then?
COMPUTER: Error confirmed as non-fatal. Error reported to technical Support. Processing can continue.
DOCTOR: Are you sure about that?
COMPUTER: Welcome, citizen. You do a great thing for your people. Please record a final message for your family after the tone.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry?
COMPUTER: Please begin recording of final message.
DOCTOR: I have no desire to leave a final message for anyone! I only want to get out of here!
COMPUTER: Then you must proceed to the End.
DOCTOR: ‘The End’. Is this what I think it is? Some kind of euthanasia program? Murdering the elders, so the young can visit the spa?
COMPUTER: Ten, nine, eight, seven, [six, five, four, three, two —]
DOCTOR: This is monstrous! Let me out at once! You have no right!
COMPUTER: One —
DOCTOR: Maybe this really is it...
DOCTOR: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 36
COMPUTER: Welcome to the End.
DOCTOR: No!!!
DOCTOR: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 37

elements.text: PART TWO
NO REPRISE
SCENE 16: INT. SUIT DOCK
FX: SOMETHING BIG AND HEAVY POWERING UP. THEN ELECTRONICS,
SIMILAR TO THE COMPUTER SOUNDS IN THE BIRTHDAY ROOM.
Activating exo-armour. Life-support at full capacity. Incoming
occupant.
FX: ‘ZASSH’ OF ENERGY — SAME AS ENDED PART ONE — THEN:
(CONTINUATION OF CRY... WHICH FALTERS AS HE REALISES HE’S NOT DEAD, JUST TELEPORTED) Nooooooo.. oh. What on Earth — (GETTING
BEARINGS) I’m inside something! Some kind of... robotic suit?
Conscript received. Locking exo-armour.
FX: METAL STRUTS SLOTTING INTO PLACE AROUND HIS ARMS AND LEGS —
ETC.
Stop that right now. I’d rather my appendages weren’t encased in heavy armour, thank you very much.
FX: SOUNDS CONTINUE.
Not that anyone ever listens to me. The universe is renowned for paying no heed! Ouch — do be careful!
FX: CLUNK, CLUNK, CLICK!
If you’re quite finished?
Initiating connectivity.
FX: SKREEEK - A DEVICE RAISES BEHIND THE DOCTOR’S HEAD.
Now, hold on back there. That looks suspiciously like a mind probe. Whatever you’re about to do, you do not have my permission to do it!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 38
Connect.
FX: DEVICE THUDS INTO THE BACK OF THE DOCTOR'S HEAD —
TRANSFER SOUNDS.
Get out of my head!
Accessing experiential logs.
You mean — my memories?
FX: POWERING UP SOUNDS.
Psychokinetic reserves at one hundred per cent. Disconnect.
FX: DEVICE COMES AWAY FROM THE DOCTOR’S HEAD.
Not a mind probe, then. You were gathering my memories like fuel.. Fuel for this suit?
Load weapons.
FX: SEVERAL LARGE GUNS ARE DRILLED ONTO THE ARMS AND BODY OF
THE DOCTOR’S SUIT.
Now that I can’t abide — desist immediately. I do not carry guns, particularly not large ones — so kindly stop attaching them to me!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 39
SCENE 17: EXT. MARKETPLACE
FX: FLIP AND OLIVIA ON THE RUN. BEHIND THEM, THE UNSEEN
CONTINUES TO SMASH THROUGH THE MARKET.
He’s making a proper mess of the market, this invisible
monster.
Fine by me, so long as the stalls are slowing him down.
FX: SMASH!
Yeah, they’re not slowing him down that much.
We need to find another way out.
FX: THEY RUN TO STOP.
(PUFFED) The other way out is, where — over the wall?
FX: THE BEAST’S HEAVY BREATHING.
I hate to say it, but I think he’s got us cornered.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 40
SCENE 18: INT. SUIT DOCK
FX: FINAL DRILLING SOUND.
Attachment of armatures complete. Disconnect activation dock.
FX: DOCK DISCONNECTS FROM DOCTOR, LEAVING HIM IN BULKY SUIT.
Can I even walk in this thing? (HE TAKES A STEP, STUMBLES) Whoah...!
FX: FALLS HEAVILY TO THE FLOOR.
Apparently not. This may take some getting used to.
FX: MECHANICAL DOOR OPENS, OFF. SOMEBODY, ALSO IN A POWER SUIT,
ENTERS AND STOMPS OVER TO THE DOCTOR. STOPS.
How are you feeling, dear?
I’ve been better. Who are you, may I ask?
My name’s Janaiya. I’ve been exactly where you are, my dear. know just how you’re feeling. All a bit much, isn’t it? Come on, let me help you up — takes a while to get used to these suits.
(BEING HELPED UP) Thank you, Janaiya. I’m the Doctor.
‘Doctor’? You can’t enlist with a name like that — you’d end Sergeant Doctor. That’s daft.
Enlist? Janaiya, where am I?
Welcome to the End. (BEAT) Kettle’s on over at the barracks. Fancy a brew?
up
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 41
SCENE 19: EXT. MARKETPLACE
FX: THE BEAST’S HEAVY BREATHING.
We could make a run for it in different directions. That way it’d only get one of us. Has it got horns, you think? It sounds like it might have horns.
FX: OVER THIS — ANOTHER DRONE ABOVE THEM.
See that drone up there?
Bit I’m more worried about what’s in front of us, T.B.H., Olivia!
Don’t worry, I’ve got a plan. Pass me the cloth from the jam stall.
What — this jam stall?
How many other jam stalls are there?
But if I pull the cloth, the jam’1ll go everywhere.
I know. Look, just trust me!
Alright. (REACHES OUT) Three, two, one — (PULLS ON TABLECLOTH)
FX: WHOLE STALL OVERTURNS, MULTIPLE JAM JARS SMASH ON FLOOR.
IMMEDIATELY, THE CREATURE REACTS, SNORTS IN ALARM.
He doesn’t like the jam!
Cloth, quickly!
FX: CLOTH PASSED — RUSTLING.
Now give me a leg-up the side of the wall.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 42
Yeah, why?
Hurry!
FLIP/OLIVIA
LEG-UP EFFORT
What now?
(CALLING) Here, you — drone! Over here!
FX: DRONE BUZZES OVER.
Little bit closer. Just a little bit closer...
FX: MONSTER SNORTS WITH DISGUST.
(WORRIED) He doesn’t like the jam on him, Olivia..! He doesn’t like it at all!
That’s it! Now — (EFFORT AS SHE THROWS CLOTH OVER DRONE) Got you!
FX: DRONE BUZZES ANGRILY — MUFFLED BY CLOTH.
Synthetic material! Optics obscured!
You’ve caught it! I get it — you’re gonna whack the monster with it!
That’s the plan. (EFFORT — SHE JUMPS DOWN TO GROUND)
FX: MONSTER SNORTS ANGRILY, STOMPING RIGHT AT FLIP...
So whack it, will you?!
SWINGS DRONE IN CLOTH — EFFORT
FX: DRONE CRASHES DOWN ON BEAST’S ‘HEAD’. IT GROANS AND
COLLAPSES.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 43
Who'd have thought? It actually worked. Nice one, Livvy!
I’m as surprised as you are.
FX: FLICKERING ELECTRICAL SOUND FROM THE BEAST — IT IS BECOMING
VISIBLE!
Hang about — the monster’s becoming visible!
Whatever was cloaking it must have been disrupted.
Horns, see? I knew it!
Like a big armoured bull up on his hind legs — with extra teeth.
FX: PULSING SOUND AND A ZAP. CLOTH FLUTTERS.
He’s vanished. Not just gone invisible again — he’s properly vanished!
I’m not surprised — they don’t want to leave any trace behind. But I’ve never heard of them using anything like that before...
Look, who are you? I thought you were spa-all-day, party-all- night girl, but now you’re like, some kind of action hero? Which is awesome, by the way.
FX: AS MARKET TRADERS BEGIN TO RE-ENTER MARKETPLACE...
TRADERS
(OFF) Has it gone? /Is it safe?/ What happened?/ Look what it’s done to my stall! [ETC — CONTINUES AS THEY RIGHT STALL
We don’t want to attract any more attention. (HEFTING DRONE —
FX: METAL SCRAPES ON FLOOR) Help me with this thing, would you?
Wait — you’re taking the drone with you?
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 44
Hopefully.
You grab it out of the air, smash it on an invisible monster’s head, and now you’re nicking it?
Handy bits of kit, these drones — lots of linked-up tech.
FX: FEW NUTS AND BOLTS FALL OFF DRONE AS SHE HEFTS IT.
Well, handy if I can keep all the bits together.
Hang on, I’1l get those.
Thanks.
So where are we taking it?
Home. And... we?
I’m coming with you. I don’t know anyone else round here — so you’re some sort of top secret ninja, I’m sticking with you.
OK - we. My flat’s not far — we can hide it there and do a little tinkering. Come on.
FX: THEY EXIT, CARRYING DRONE.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 45
SCENE 20: INT. ARMY BARRACKS
FX: HEAVY, HYDRAULIC FOOTSTEPS AS THE DOCTOR AND JANAIYA EMERGE
INTO A HUGE UNDERGROUND MILITARY CAMP. LOTS OF NOISE, TARGET PRACTICE, MOVEMENT. HUNDREDS OF OTHER MECH SUITS, STOMPING,
TARGET PRACTICE ETC.
You have... quite an army down here.
Yes, it’s lovely, isn’t it? Noisy, mind - with all that clanking and shonking — I don’t always get a good night’s rest. This way, Doctor...!
FX: CROSS TO —
Computer, push that target back thirty metres.
FX: TARGET SLIDES BACK, OFF.
Target now at one hundred and thirty metres.
FX: AS DOCTOR AND JANAITYA COME OVER —
(CALLING) Hey, newbie, watch this. Lock and load!
FX: HE RELOADS MASSIVE ARM CANNON WITH A SINGLE MOTION.
Aaaand — fire!!!
FX: HIS CANNON OPENS FIRE MASSIVELY — THE TARGET IS DESTROYED.
Target... has ceased to exist.
(BLOWING HIS SMOKING CANNON) Not bad, huh?
Doctor, I’d like you to meet my husband, Roman.
Nice to meet you, soldier.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 46
I thought this was a euthanasia programme, but it’s recruitment. You’re building an army here. A mech-suited army of... well...
You can say it, we’re not shy round these parts.
Well, none of you are exactly spring chickens.
I’m eighty-two. And — dear, do you mind me saying?
I’m seventy-eight years old.

Same as our whole battalion. All over seventy, all armed to the teeth, all war heroes in waiting. We have octogenarians, nonagenarians, even a lady in the First Armoured Corps who’s just turned a hundred and four. The End is the beginning, as they say.
Yes, so they do. Well, it’s very impressive. More power to your electronic elbow.
You see old Harry over there? He’s the best sniper we have — eighty-nine years old and absolutely deadly with that ocular attachment. Also, a demon at cribbage.
He’s just showing off now.

Why shouldn’t I — I’m proud of our army. Take me - I’ve got severe arthritis, bad hip, cataracts, irregular heartbeat and none of my own teeth — but this suit makes me a fully-armoured, nicely sedated pain in the backside. You can’t argue with that kind of quality of life, can you?
That’s largely wonderful — apart from all the guns.
What’s that?
Er.. Roman and I celebrated our fifty-first wedding anniversary last week, Doctor.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 47
Congratulations. Though I can’t imagine these suits go well with a candlelit meal?
Oh, we made it work. Means he can still pick me up anyway — carry me across the threshold and all that.
Fifty-one years... It’s gone in a flash, hasn’t it? I remember our first date - at the ice rink. You showed me how to go backwards.
Now, don’t get soppy. We’ve got a guest.
I’ll take every opportunity to be soppy. You have to when you’re getting ready for war.
War? You’re going to war?
We’re all going to war — you included, Doctor.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 48
SCENE 21: INT. MIDDLE OFFICE
FX: CONSTANCE IS ASLEEP AT A DESK.
Time to wake up, my dear.
(AWAKES WITH A START) What? Where am I?
We don’t take kindly to staff falling asleep at their desks — but as you’re a new arrival, I'll let it slide.
Am I back at Bletchley?
I have no idea what you’re saying.
No... all glass, all windows... this must be...
This is the Middle — welcome.
The Middle...

And happy birthday. Thirty-five is a year of new responsibility. There will be a welcome celebration for you at the end of the working day — with cake - but for now, just get your feet under the table, try and introduce yourself around. If I were you, I'd get a few hot drinks in, that always helps.
Where are my friends?
I have no idea — and it’s certainly no concern of yours. I know you’ve had thirty-five years of ease, but this is where you knuckle down and start to pay us back.
Pay you back?
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 49

Our scan detects that you have an affinity for systems monitoring and deciphering — so I’m going to put you on surveillance. The End is mobilising as we speak, so why don’t you start by keeping an eye on them for any irregularities. We need to be sharp — so look for anything rough.
FX: HE PRESSES A BUTTON ON THE DESK. SCREEN ACTIVATES, SHOWING
LEGIONS OF MECH-SUITS.
Good gracious. All those old people - what are they wearing?
Please, be respectful. Our army may be ancient, but it is equipped, trained and managed to perfection.
They’re like tanks — everybody’s walking around in a tank.

Yes. Sure. Oh, and keep an eye on this one, in particular — new recruit. His readings were very unusual, but sometimes the unusual conscripts can make the best fighters. The suit draws on their more pronounced experiences.
FX: SWITCHES FREQUENCY SO IMAGE OF THE DOCTOR, TALKING TO ROMAN
AND JANAITYA APPEARS. DUB IN FROM PREVIOUS SCENE —
. Well, it’s very impressive. More power to your electronic elbow. [ETC]
Doct— (STOPS HERSELF) — oh. Yes, I see.
Don’t be fooled, a lot of facelifts among that lot. (CURIOUS) Still, that’s excellent work. Doesn’t look a day over forty...
I’ll keep an eye on him, shall I?
Yes. Yes, thank you...
Constance. Mrs Constance Clarke.
Nice to meet you, Constance. I am the Middleman. You may call me Sir.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 50
SCENE 22: INT. ARMY BARRACKS
So you’re an army of the elderly.
Oi, less of that.
Look, I’m all for the empowerment of the older generation — you can do whatever you want to do. But why? Why create a force like this?

These suits — they draw power from our memories, our experiences. So us older folk, we’ve got the greatest resource of all: a good long life. We’re veterans already, aren’t we? The more you’ve lived, the stronger you are. No need to send the kids out to fight when we can do it for ‘em — they’re better off making babies.
FX: SOUNDS OF THE ARMY ALL AROUND THEM.
Ants...
I’m sorry?

In an ant colony, the young are protected, and it’s the oldest ants who are sent out of the nest to carry out all the most dangerous jobs. They’ve lived a life, they’ve served the queen well, and they’re now expendable. Protect the young, protect the queen. They dutifully trot out and carry the biggest seeds, scout the most dangerous terrain and defend the colony against attackers until their dying breath.
So we’re ants then, are we?
Growing old does not make you expendable. But somebody round here obviously sees it that way.
I used to keep one of those little ant farms — so you can see through the side. They all looked the same to me — young or old.
A society turned on its head.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 51
Whatever you say. Look, we’ve got an inspection coming and you’d better be smartly turned out. Has Janaiya shown you basic movement?
I think I’ve got it. Walking is just... think it, lean into ita little and...
FX: DOCTOR’S RIGHT FOOT CLUNKS FORWARD. BUT HE STUMBLES — STEAM
AND SIRENS SOUNDING ON HIS SUIT.
Whoops! I feel like a fawn learning to walk.
Pretty big fawn.

You’ve just got to think it as deep as you can. It can help to summon up a memory — to add fuel to the fire. Try not to make it too profound a recollection — tends to jam the suits up a bit. Just keep it light for now — think happy thoughts, happy memories.
Yes. I feel very uneasy about all of this. The inside of my head is not a place fit for machines. There aren’t many straight lines in there.

Whatever you say. Right, let’s show you how your artillery works. You’ve got your ten-thousand-round minigun here, and on the other arm there’s your phased plasma rifle — that one can give a real kick...
That won’t be necessary, Roman. I’m not one for firearms, and I certainly won’t be turned into a weapon.
You’ve not got a lot of choice, I reckon.
We'll see about that. I don’t intend to stay cooped up in this suit of armour against my will. Let’s see...
FX: HE FIDDLES WITH THE ARM — PRESSES A FEW BUTTONS.
If I can just recalibrate the...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 52
Good luck with that.
No... or maybe I can...
FX: DOCTOR PRESSES BUTTONS — CLICK CLICK CLICK. THEN A LOUD
COMES BACK AT HIM.
Well, there’s no need to be rude.
Doctor, the suit is part of you now — no need to fiddle with it. You’ll work in it, sleep in it, do everything in it.
Yeah, everything.
Thank you, dear.
So I’m a prisoner? We’re all prisoners.
FX: ROMAN IS BACK TO DOING HIS TARGET PRACTICE, LOCKING AND
AS HE TALKS.
Actually, we don’t see it like that.
Well, how do you see it?
This here’s an honour. We’re fighting for our people —
For our grandchildren.

Doctor, I played with model soldiers when I was a boy, and I looked up to my Granddad when he joined up. All I wanted to do was be like him. And now I am. We fight for our world. We’re the End — we’ve been put in these suits to fight to the bitter one. And you’1ll be fighting alongside, I have no doubt.
I am not... I will not fight anyone. I am not a soldier.
CROSS TO —
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 53
SCENE 23: INT. MIDDLE OFFICE [CONTINUOUS]
FX: ROMAN AND DOCTOR HEARD OVER MONITORS.
(D) If you’re no soldier, then coward you are.
(D) Well. So be it.
FX: THEY HEAD OFF IN DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS. JUST AMBIENT
NOISE RUNS UNDERNEATH —
What are you up to, Doctor...?
I’m sorry, I didn’t quite catch that.
(MOMENTARILY STARTLED) Ah! (COLLECTS HERSELF) A computing machine that talks to you. How... disarming.
I am here to assist you.
Very well. Tell me everything I can do from here. From this desk.
You have access to all monitoring equipment on Formicia.
FX: PING! REMINDER SOUND.
Reminder: You have one birthday allocation.
I do wish people would stop rabbiting on about my birthday.
You are allocated one birthday message. You will receive your next allocation in twelve months’ time.
Well, why didn’t you say? Happy birthday to me. Can I contact anyone?
You may use your birthday allocation to send a one-way message to any one individual on Formicia.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 54
Then... I would like to send a message to the Doctor. (SOTTO) Sorry, Flip...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 55
SCENE 24: EXT. CITY PARK
FX: FLIP AND OLIVIA WALKING QUICKLY, PAST CARNIVAL REVELLING
(AS BEFORE). STILL CARRYING DRONE.
Hang about, can we put this drone of yours down a minute? It’s heavier than it looks.
Alright, but not for long.
FX: THEY STOP. CARNIVAL SOUNDS CARRY.
What’s all that? Another party?
The all-nighters start early — they’1ll be going from now till the sun comes up.
I used to like that. Find it all a bit exhausting now.

Welcome to my world. I’m sick of it. The young people on Formicia — they’re smart, they’re really smart — but they don’t use it, they just muck about. It’s all parties and hangovers, whilst an army goes to war in our name. And there’s more and more of us who just aren’t accepting that as the status quo.
So you’re.. what are you? A secret agent? Undercover as a spoilt little rich kid?

I’m not undercover — I’m me. I just.. I have to wear that face you first met to get by, to not get noticed. But I’d much rather not wear it. I play the game, but underneath I’ve got my own game. I want to change all this - bring it down.
Alright! Can I help?
Look, where are you three from? I mean, really?
Ok. Right. You’re giving straight answers so maybe I owe you a few two. The Doctor, Constance and I — we’re not from round here.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 56
You’re from the outskirts?
The out-outskirts. Really out. A few light years out. The outer-space-skirts.
You’re kidding.
I’m not, you know.

It was three generations back. In the days when the old were just left to be old. A Kronvos invasion force was gathering on the surface. Awful, ugly things. Our people had to defend their homes. On the first day of recruitment, nearly a million young men and women enlisted. They went away to fight. And they did not come back.

DEAFENING: SCENE 57: INT. MIDDLEMAN’S SUITE
MIDDLEMAN: No.. no, that’s not possible...
CONSTANCE: That’1ll be the Doctor, then.
CONSTANCE: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 109
CONSTANCE: SCENE 58: INT. GREAT CAVE
JANAIYA: The Kronvos — they’re frozen...
OLIVIA: Frozen in their tracks.
DOCTOR: And entirely harmless. I hope. (TURNS TO STOMP OFF)
FLIP: Hang about, where are you going?
JANAIYA: You can’t go into the Kronvos line!
JANAIYA: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 110
JANAIYA: SCENE 59: INT. GREAT CAVE — AMONG KRONVOS [CONTINUOUS]
FROZEN: KRONVOS ARMY.
DOCTOR: (LOUDLY) There was no Kronvos Army. There never was. You see this chap here?
DOCTOR: This is no soldier. This is a solid-state hologram. Capable of weight, touch, killing, even — but not actually real!
JANAIYA: This can’t be...
DOCTOR: I reprogrammed Flip’s cannon to overload their holo-matrix. Their whole Horde is a fake. (LOUDLY AGAIN) You — the End — you are brave and valiant, but you have been deceived. There is no army for you to fight.
JANAIYA: But why... why?
DOCTOR: Maybe the Middleman can shed some light on that.
MIDDLEMAN: (D) You again! — I knew I should have disposed of you —
DOCTOR: . when you had the chance?
MIDDLEMAN: (D).1 SELLA Can.
FLIP: He’s got a point. Probably best not to remind him.
DOCTOR: Yes, well — before you do, Middleman: would you care to explain to your army why they have no-one to fight? Why your war was a lie?
DOCTOR: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 111
JANAIYA: A lie.. it was all a lie... my Roman...
MIDDLEMAN: (D) The Kronvos were necessary to test my army — to see if our heroes are truly ready. But none of them matter anymore, and that’s your fault. (ASIDE) Computer, delete Kronvos.
END: TROOPS [WILDTRACK]
MIDDLEMAN: (D) The Doctor, is it? Well, Doctor — you’ve just ruined the experiment. A hundred years’ work, ruined — pff!
DOCTOR: What do you mean, ‘experiment’?
MIDDLEMAN: (D) We’d found a new shape for society — a new shape that worked. And you’ve just charged in and destroyed it.
DOCTOR: If that means an end to this phoney war, then I think that’s very good news.
MIDDLEMAN: (D) Well, you say that. But I have no need for this lab anymore. I want it wiped clean. I want no-one to ever know it was ever here. And so: the rats can help me clean the lab.
FLIP: Doctor... what’s he on about?
MIDDLEMAN: (D; ALOUD) Hear me, army of mine. The End is not the beginning. The End is just that — there is nothing more.
JANAIYA: No... !
MIDDLEMAN: (D; ALOUD) You are each installed in an armoured suit of my design. Which means: I can over-ride the control of each and every one. Army — turn, about face!
MIDDLEMAN: THE OTHER WAY — INCLUDING THE DOCTOR’S SUIT.
MIDDLEMAN: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 112
JANAIYA: I can’t stop myself.
FLIP: Me neither.
DOCTOR: (TO MIDDLEMAN) What are you playing at now?
MIDDLEMAN: (D; ALOUD) You will all now return to the city.. and you will raze it to the ground!!
DOCTOR: What?!
MIDDLEMAN: (D; ALOUD) You will destroy everything and everyone in the city. Your families included.
JANAIYA: No — you can’t make us!
DOCTOR: This is monstrous! (FORCED TO MARCH) Ahh!
MIDDLEMAN: Go forth my army - go forth, and wipe the slate clean. Then, maybe, we can start all over again.
MIDDLEMAN: END OF PART THREE
MIDDLEMAN: #232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 113

elements.text: PART FOUR
NO REPRISE
SCENE 60: INT. MIDDLEMAN’S SUITE
It isn’t my birthday, but I’d like to send a message. Computer, you can deliver this to all families in Formicia.
FX: BEEP TONE.

Hello. I wanted to let you all know how much I care about you. I’ve been your Middleman for nearly two decades and it’s been an honour to see Formicia grow. We’ve cheered as our elder citizens have joined the ranks of the End and prepared for a War that would protect and strengthen us all. I am here to tell you now that this War is over and we have lost. You have lost. Please hug your loved ones close and think well on the happy moments in your life. Death is coming to you. You will recognise your attackers — and maybe that is the end we all deserve. This society was a great experiment. But all experiments can fail. We have failed, I have failed — and for that, I am sorry. Message ends.
(TO CONSTANCE) Do you think I got the tone right, Mrs Clarke?
I’m not sure why you’re even bothering — you evidently have nothing but contempt for your people.

I am a Middleman. The clue is in the name. I simply follow orders. My superiors on the surface couldn’t care less about the test subjects, so neither do I. We’ve violated the terms of the test study, so that’s it, over, pointless — who cares?
(SARCASTIC) No, indeed: why care about any of the men, women and children you’ve just sentenced to death?
I’m glad we see eye-to-eye on this. I shall be on my way up now, I think. Computer — initialise exo-armour.
FX: WALL PANEL OPENS. MIDDLEMAN’S EXO-ARMOUR IS REVEALED.
Exo-Ssuit ready for integration.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 114
Let’s hope this still fits me. I’ve had a few dinners since the last time I wore it.
FX: AS THE CONVERSATION CONTINUES, THE MIDDLEMAN’S SUIT IS
ITSELF TO HIS BODY, WITH HYDRAULICS.
What kind of “experiment” was it, anyhow? What was the point?

It began with a question: what use are the old? They retire, they consume precious resources, and then they fade away. But we wanted more from our ageing citizens. We wanted them to prove their worth — not to sponge off the state, but to defend it. And then — if the worst happened, and they didn’t come home from the battlefield, well... surely that’d be better than sacrificing the young?
Where I’m from, we lost many of our young men — and women. They wouldn’t have wanted to send anyone else in their place, least of all their grandmothers. They had courage. Where is your courage?
‘Courage’! What a strange idea. (FX: SUIT SEALED) Goodbye, Mrs Clarke. Run along and die with the rest of the experiment — at the hands of those who love you. Your ‘Doctor’, quite possibly...
FX: HE STEPS THROUGH AN AUTOMATIC DOOR. IT SHUTS. CONSTANCE IS
ALONE.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 115
SCENE 61: EXT. CITY STREET
FX: STOMPING OF SUITS FROM BEHIND GLASS. SUDDENLY A SMASH! AS
THE DOCTOR AND FLIP CRASH THROUGH. AS THEY PROCEED, FORCIBLY MARCHED.
Are these suits gonna force us to smash through everything?
So it would appear. — The main population centre isn’t far ahead. I dread to think of the destruction we’re capable of wreaking.
There must be a way out of this! Mustn’t there?
It’s not windows and bus shelters I’m worried about. It’s Mrs Clarke.
Connie? (REALISATION) The Middleman, he said we’d all have to kill our families...
For us, that means Mrs Clarke. Who’s still in the Middle, I presume, to judge by our direction of travel.
FX: A THIRD SUIT STOMPING ALONG, JUST AHEAD.
(POINTING OUT) Yeah, and we’re not the only troops headed that way. Look, up there on the flyover — it’s Livvy!
Who’s she being forced to target, I wonder...?
FX: CRUMBLING MASONRY ABOVE. CONTINUES THROUGH —
She’s stomped holes in the flyover. It’s breaking up! — Er, how do we make these things stop?
We don’t. We just have to hope the suits can take the weight of the flyover.
You mean...?
FX: FLYOVER COLLAPSES ON TOP OF THEM.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 116
& FLIP (BURIED) Aaaaaaaaaaah!
FX: FALLEN MASONRY SETTLES.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 117
SCENE 62: INT. MIDDLEMAN’S SUITE
(TRYING TO WAKE HIM) Mr York? Mr York? Callum, can you hear me?
(GROGGY) Mrs Clarke...? The Middleman, he —
. shot you with a tranquillising ray of some description.
Right. So where is he now?
He strapped on an armoured suit, and went to see his paymasters. But he’s the least of our problems now.
Why...?
FX: SIDE WALL OF NEXT ROOM SMASHED IN. A SUIT STOMPING THROUGH.
That’s why. The Middleman has abandoned this ‘experiment’.
‘Experiment’ ?
The army are here!! Head down, Mr York...!
FX: SUIT SMASHES THROUGH GLASS PARTITION. STOMPS TO STOP.
DAD!
Olivia..? What are you doing here?
Dad — get out! Get away from me!!
But —
FX: OLIVIA’S ARMATURE LOCKS AND LOADS.
You don’t understand, Callum! The Middleman’s reprogrammed the suits —
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 118
. and mine is targeting you!
What?!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 119
SCENE 63: INT. SUBURBAN HALLWAY
FX: DISTANT STOMPING, ARMATURE FIRE, SIRENS.
What are those noises...? — Computer: update, please.
No data available. Middle advises: stay in your home.
Well, something’s going on. All that smoke in the air, and those sirens!
FX: OUTSIDE — JANAIYA STOMPS THROUGH GARDEN GATE, LITERALLY,
AND TOWARDS DOOR THROUGH...
What the..? — That was right outside the house!
Repeat. Middle advises: stay in your home.
They’re coming here...!
FX: OUTSIDE — STOMPING PAUSES; HYDRAULIC WHIRR. THEN — FRONT
SMASHED ONTO FLOOR. BABY BEGINS TO CRY UPSTAIRS.
SHRIEKS
(FX: STOMPING IN) Get away from me, Chloe!
Mum?! What are you — what are you doing here...?
Please, you have to get away!
FX: WEAPONS RAISE, LOCK ONTO CHLOE.
Mum?? Sophie’s upstairs — you can’t -
I can’t control the suit, Chloe. You have to get away! Take Sophie and get away from me, before...
FX: HER WEAPON OPENS FIRE.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 120
SCENE 64: INT. MIDDLEMAN’S SUITE
FX: OLIVIA IS STILL ADVANCING ON CALLUM AND CONSTANCE.
(CONCENTRATION EFFORT THROUGHOUT) It wants me to fire, but I don’t want to shoot! Tell me how not to make the armature shoot!
Callum. Callum!! — You helped design the drone machines. What do you know about these suits?
I — I remember seeing a report, about a glitch in the software...
And?!
And there’s a way — I think — to overload the system...
FX: GRINDING HYDRAULICS.
Dad, please! It wants me to raise my arm! I can’t stop it!!
(TO YORK) What can she do, Callum?!
The suit draws psychokinetic power from the wearer’s memories — from their experiences. But there’s only so much energy it can take in one go.
So I can overload the system how, exactly?
By focusing on your memories. Summon up the most powerful memories you have, and it should cause the system to shut down.
Why would that even work?
We discovered that... when the troopers died, they burned out the system. It’s true what they say: that your whole life flashes in front of your eyes, just before the end.
But I can’t think of anything!!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 121
Olivia, you have to try!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 122
SCENE 65: INT. SUBURBAN HALLWAY
FX: ARMATURE WINDS DOWN. BABY STILL CRYING UPSTAIRS.
Mum? Mum, you nearly killed me —
(CONCENTRATION EFFORT) Chloe, please! It took everything I had to direct my arm away. I don’t want to shoot! I’d do anything not to make it shoot! But I can’t stop it!
I — I have to fetch Sophie...
Then run, Chloe! Run!!
FX: AS CHLOE RUSHES UPSTAIRS...
Roman — I wish you were here, you’d know what to do... stupid suit — stop... stop moving.. I refuse this. I refuse I refuse I refuse!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 123
SCENE 66: INT. MIDDLEMAN’S SUITE
Olivia — you have to concentrate!
Please, Olivia...!

Alright, Dad, alright! — I remember... I remember the day they came and took you away. It was your birthday and Mum and me had made a little cake. And you looked at me and you seemed so sad, but you it was like you’d always known. I hugged you so hard, and then...
Then what?
Olivia, you have to remember!

Then the robots came to take you away — the ones they had before the drones — and then... then me and Mum, we just sat there on the floor, and ate the cake. Mum wasn’t well even then, I knew. But it was the last time the three of us were all together.
FX: SUDDENLY — A POWERING DOWN SOUND. THE SUIT IS IDLING.
Wait... did that work?
You did it! You’ve burned out the automatic guidance!
FX: OLIVIA FLEXES HER LEGS AND ARMS.
It’s back under my control. (RELIEF) Oh, Dad...!
Yes, the family reunion can wait. The Middleman sent the entire army of the End to do the exact same thing to their families as you were about to do to him.
What?
Your friend’s right. Dad, you need to tell each and every trooper how to overload their suits.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 124
Me?!
This is the Middleman’s suite, is it not? This is his, er,
‘workstation’?
(REALISATON) Yes, yes of course...!
Then you can send out a message on the Middleman’s frequency!
FX: YORK ACTIVATES KEYBOARD.
This is the Middle, with a message to all soldiers of the End...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 125
SCENE 67: INT. SUBURBAN HALLWAY
FX: DOOR SLAMS UPSTAIRS. CHLOE COMES HURRYING HALFWAY DOWN,
CRYING BABY. STOPS. JANAIYA’S HYDRAULICS SWIVEL.
Mum, let me pass. I’m taking Sophie and I’m leaving. Sophie, your grand-daughter. Mum, let me pass!
It won’t let me let you go, Chloe. The suit. I can’t — can’t stop it.
FX: WEAPON POWERING UP.
I’m sorry...!
Mum, don’t!
FX: CRACKLE. YORK IS HEARD OVER JANAIYA’S COMM CHANNEL.
(D; FIRST SENTENCE FROM PREVIOUS SCENE) This is the Middle, with a message to all soldiers of the End...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 126
SCENE 68: EXT. CITY STREET
FX: HUGE PILE OF RUBBLE SHOVED ASIDE BY SUIT HYDRAULICS.
There! Takes more than a falling flyover to flatten a Flip!
In these suits, certainly. Which is interesting.
Why’s that then-? (FX: SUDDEN WHIRRING AS SUITS DRAG THEM AWAY) Whoa! We’re off again.
FX: THEY STOMP OVER WRECKAGE, RESUMING PREVIOUS COURSE.
We’re all but invulnerable in these suits. But we saw soldiers of the End being killed by Kronvos energy weapons.
So, either the Kronvos holograms emitted energy beams purposely designed to penetrate these suits, or the suits were purposely designed with that particular vulnerability built in...
Right! And you want to find out what that is so people can shoot us dead, too? Doctor, we’re not the monsters!
In these suits, we are! There must be some way to stop us...
FX: CRACKLE. YORK IS HEARD OVER JANAIYA’S COMM CHANNEL.
(D; FIRST SENTENCE FROM PREVIOUS SCENE) This is the Middle,
with a message to all soldiers of the End...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 127
SCENE 69: INT. SUBURBAN HALLWAY
FX: YORK’S SPEECH CONTINUES.
(D) We think there’s a way to shut down the suits’ automatic targeting, by overwhelming their systems with psychokinetic energy.
Psycho-what?
Ssh!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 128
SCENE 70: EXT. CITY STREET
(D) Please, just trust me on this! Imagine your whole life flashing before your eyes. Pick out your strongest memories — good ones, bad ones, doesn’t matter.
What’s the point of that?
No, no, it might work!
(D) Then hold that thought. Shut out everything else! Please, it’s the only way!
FX: CRACKLE — COMMS OFF.
Come off it!
Psychokinetic energy is a tangible force. It’s got to be worth a try! — Think of something in your past.
I can’t!
Anything!
I can’t!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 129
SCENE 71: INT. SUBURBAN HALLWAY

I remember... the day you were born, Chloe. Roman and I transmatted to the hospital — we were in such a rush, he said not to worry about the side effects on the bump. He was so worried, so scared, and then when you arrived, it all just fell away. Roman just couldn’t stop smiling — he was smiling at you and he was smiling at me.
Oh, Mum...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 130
SCENE 72: EXT. CITY STREET
Really I can’t!
There must be something, Flip! Like the man said: imagine your whole life, flashing before your eyes...
Oh well, I get that loads. I got that when I was getting married.
Your wedding day! Perfect!
Only then I was thinking about that time I jumped out of Earth orbit. ‘Taking the plunge’, you know?
Well, think about that then!
Except the time I jumped out of Earth orbit, I was thinking about that time in Scotland, with the Wirrn, when I crashed that stupid microlite on the ice.
So concentrate on that!
Only then, I was thinking about that time I got shot and killed by the Porcian leader — uh, Krarm! Krarn? No, Krarm. He was funny.
(FRUSTRATION) Fli-i-p!
Only when that happened — Oh! Yeah! (LAUGHS) I was thinking about that forest in Belgium. After Waterloo. The Forritt-des- Swines —
Forét de Soignes —
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 131

That’s the one. I’d left Jared in the Dalek pursuit ship, and gone off with you to see your TARDIS for the first time. And on the way, when I asked you what your TARDIS time machine looked like, you were being all cryptic and (SING-SONG) ‘I know something you don’t,’ like you were laughing to yourself —
I was not!

Whose memory is this - mine or yours? Yeah: smirking to yourself ‘cos you knew I was thinking it was gonna be like some shiny Star Wars spaceship doodah, when all it was was a blue box, and you couldn’t wait for me see it then walk in and go ‘O.M.G., it’s bigger on the inside than the out. O.M.G., O.M.G.,’ like a right idiot.
FX: FLIP’S SUIT POWERS DOWN. SHE DOESN'T NOTICE AND CARRIES ON.

So when we finally got there, I thought I’d best play it cool, like Jared did the first time we met at the disco in the community centre, cos he didn’t want me to think he was an idiot, when he so obviously was — sorry, sorry, going off the point.
FX: DOCTOR’S SUIT POWERS DOWN. FLIP DOESN'T NOTICE THAT EITHER.

Aaanyway. That’s why, when you finally showed me inside the TARDIS, and it was bigger on the inside than the out — which was pretty amazeballs, I’ve got to admit — I just went (SARCASTIC) ‘Ooooo’ in, like, this ironic voice? Even though I was really going ‘O.M.G.’ inside. And me going ‘Ooo0oo’ like that put your nose so far out of joint that you disappeared off to watch cricket for, like, seven light years and — (BREAKS OFF) What are you looking at me like that for?
I’m not looking at you like anything.
Smirking! — This suit’s shut down, hasn’t it?
Indeed it has. Well done, Flip.
It shut down ages ago, didn’t it? And you just let me carry on, like a proper nana!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 132
Forgive me. I was trying to focus on my own thoughts.
I bet you were. What was it then, your memory?
Ah, that’s for me to know.
Oh, go on — was it something back from, what’s it called — Gallifrey?
Like I said. For me to know.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 133
SCENE 73: INT. SUBURBAN HALLWAY
FX: JANAIYA’S SUIT POWERS DOWN.
At last. Oh Chloe — I’m so sorry. I didn’t mean any of that to happen...!
Mum, it’s so good to see you.
You too, my dear! You too!
FX: PART OF THE CEILING FALLS IN.
Shame about the house.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 134
SCENE 74: INT. MIDDLE ATRIUM/SURFACE LIFT
FX: THE MIDDLEMAN STOMPS TO A STOP OUTSIDE ONE OF THE GREAT
ATRIUM LIFTS.
Computer, elevator programme three-seven-four.
Activated. Destination: the surface.
FX: LIFT DOOR OPENS AND THE MIDDLEMAN STEPS INSIDE. THEY CLOSE
HIM. MIDDLEMAN OPENS HIS COMM LINK AS THE LIFT STARTS TO
UPWARDS.
Middleman to Lab Tech. Violet, come in please.
(D) Hello, Middleman — how’s your war?
It’s over. Some fool at the End has ruined the whole experiment.
(D) How?
That can wait. The point is: the army knows everything. I’ve no choice but to abandon Formicia.
(D) That is... disappointing. A hundred years of investment — for what?
Well, the data I’ve gathered may yet prove invaluable...
(D) Let’s hope so. Or we shall have to reconsider your future career.
I’m on my way up to the surface. Will you meet me?
I look forward to it.
FX: LIFT KEEPS ZOOMING UP.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 135
SCENE 75: EXT. CITY STREET
It would seem that we are no longer imprisoned inside these suits, So...
FX: HYDRAULIC PFF AS HE OPENS UP THE HATCH ON HIS CHEST.
You’re not trying to work out how to get of that, are you?
Oddly enough — yes.
You sure that’s wise? All this isn’t over yet. We need to find Connie, for starters.
FX: DOCTOR’S COMM LINK BUZZES.
(D) Doctor, Mrs Ramon — are you receiving me?
She appears to have found us. — Mrs Clarke! You’re in the Middle, I presume?
(D) Indeed. The Middleman’s army has ground to a halt, thanks to my friend Mr York, and his daughter.
Livvy! Is Livvy there?
(D) But as for the Middleman himself — he’s in his own suit, and by the looks of things he’s accessed a secret executive Litt.
You mean he’s getting away?
(D) My suspicion is, he’s heading for the surface.
I thought the surface was off-limits?
(D) So did everyone.
FX: JANAIYA STOMPING UP IN B/G THROUGH —
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 136
Right then. Just as well we’re still wearing these suits, isn’t at?
(CAUTION) Flip...
FX: JANAIYA ARRIVES.
Doctor! There you are.
Oh — hey, Janaiya. Me and the Doctor are just going after the Middleman.
I said no such thing!
Mind if I join you?
FX: SHE RELOADS HER WEAPON.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 137
SCENE 76: INT. SURFACE LIFT
FX: MIDDLEMAN’S LIFT IS STILL SPEEDING UP INTO THE SKY.
Two minutes to arrival on surface.
Thank you, Computer. I’1l miss this view. Not a bad sphere, really. There’ll be other testing grounds, I know, but I grew to rather like Formicia. Ah well.
Alert. Detecting damage to exterior lift track.
Above us?!
FX: NOISE FROM BELOW — THREE EXO-SUITS BOUNCING UP THE OUTSIDE
OF THE TOWER — SMASH, SMASH, SMASH! CONTINUES THROUGH —
Below.
What?! (LOOKING DOWN) Three exo-suits leaping up the outside of the tower. Now that is not something I expected to see...
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 138
SCENE 77: EXT. TOWER
FX: WIND RIPS AROUND THE TOWER AS THE DOCTOR, FLIP AND JANAIYA
UP AFTER THE MIDDLEMAN, ALL IN ARMOURED SUITS.
I feel like a big robot squirrel going up a tree.
I just hope our magnetic clamps hold out.
Up there, Doctor — I can see the Middleman’s great glass elevator, right up by the cavern roof!
Yeah, well, he’s not getting away from us now..! (EFFORT AS THEY...)
FX: CONTINUE CLIMBING.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 139
SCENE 78: EXT. SURFACE
FX: PASTORAL AMBIENCE — BIRDS ETC. THE MIDDLEMAN’S LIFT EMERGES
FROM THE GROUND AND COMES TO A FINAL STOP. GLASS DOOR SLIDING OPEN. MIDDLEMAN EMERGES, STILL IN HIS EXO-SUIT.
Oh, it’s good to be back on the surface, after so long. Now - where’s that transport I was promised...?
(FROM LIFT) Warning. Unauthorised incursion onto surface.
I’m entitled to be here, you know!
FX: THREE SUITS SMASH THROUGH THE BASE OF THE GLASS ELEVATOR.
Oh, you mean them!
FX: DOCTOR, FLIP AND JANAIYA LEAP OUT OF ELEVATOR — THEIR BOOTS
STRIKING THE GROUND IN SEQUENCE.
The surface, at last!
Nice here, innit?
Another lie. They told us the surface was ruined, devastated by war.
Don’t be so dense. There was no war — no Kronvos has ever existed. It’s always been perfectly fine up here. You lot just needed to think you’d lost a generation, for... motivational reasons.
So what happened to them? The ‘lost generation’?
Oh, they were given a sphere of their own, as an experiment. They’re still around here somewhere, I believe, the great- great-grandparents. All body hair and sharpened teeth.
That’s monstrous!
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 140
Nothing to do with me — I’m relatively new to the job, just following on, really. Any objections, you’1ll have to take them up with my employers.
You know, I think I’d rather like to meet your employers.
You may get your wish — they’1l be picking me up at any moment.
Are they now?
I’d go back to Formicia if I were you. You do realise they’1l kill you?
You do realise I’m going to kill you first?!
FX: STEPS FORWARD TOWARDS THE MIDDLEMAN.
I have... no idea who you are. Who are you, dear?
My name is Janaiya and I was one of your soldiers. My husband Roman was one of your soldiers too. He died for your cause.
And did he believe in it?
Y-yes, but —
Well then, I’m sure he died happy.
You what?

You may not want to hear it, but all we ever wanted was to give you a reason to live. And to die. Look — am I to take it you want to fight me? Because I feel I should I warn you, my suit’s an executive upgrade...
(LEAPS ON HIM) Animal!!!
FX: THEY BEGIN TO FIGHT. BIG HYDRAULIC PUNCHES.
#232: THE MIDDLE by Chris Chapman (FINAL) Page 141
SCENE 79: INT. MIDDLEMAN’S SUITE
FX: AN ALARM SOUNDS.
Alert. Structural damage to Middle Tower. Integrity compromised.
What?
FX: CHITTERING DATA STREAM.
Dad — these readings...!
Cracks spreading down through the superstructure, from two miles up.
How?

MIDDLEMAN: It isn’t my birthday, but I’d like to send a message. Computer, you can deliver this to all families in Formicia.
MIDDLEMAN: Hello. I wanted to let you all know how much I care about you. I’ve been your Middleman for nearly two decades and it’s been an honour to see Formicia grow. We’ve cheered as our elder citizens have joined the ranks of the End and prepared for a War that would protect and strengthen us all. I am here to tell you now that this War is over and we have lost. You have lost. Please hug your loved ones close and think well on the happy moments in your life. Death is coming to you. You will recognise your attackers — and maybe that is the end we all deserve. This society was a great experiment. But all experiments can fail. We have failed, I have failed — and for that, I am sorry. Message ends.
